title: Attribute & Role Mapping
content:
# Attribute & Role Mapping

The Attribute Mapping/Role Mapping is a functionality in Umbraco SAML 2.0 plugin which is used to map the user attributes/roles in IDP with the ASP.NET.

Attribute Mapping - Attribute mapping involves mapping user attributes from the IdP with the ASP.NET user attributes.

Role Mapping - Role mapping is the process of mapping user roles from the IdP with the ASP.NET user roles.

This tab contains the following 3 sections:
- How Basic Attribute Mapping Works
Attributes are the user details that are stored in your Identity Provider. These attributes include Username, Email, First Name, Last Name, Group/Role, Display Name, etc. The Attribute Mapping feature helps you to map these user attributes sent by the IDP to the ASP.NET user attributes.

By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.

You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.

The image below shows the basic attributes which are sent from the Identity Provider appropriately added and mapped with their  equivalent ASP.NET SAML Plugin attributes

How Custom Attribute Mapping Works

It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to the ASP.NET users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.

Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no.,Permanant Address, City, State, Department etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.

For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the Identity Provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

- For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the Identity Provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the Identity Provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

- How Role Mapping Works

This feature can be used to assign and manage roles of the users when they perform SSO. Along with the default ASP.NET roles, this is compatible with any custom roles as well.

This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IdP attribute Group values.

Before enabling this setting, please make sure you’ve configured the attribute name in the Group/Role field of the Attribute Mapping section.

For e.g.: You can map your IdPs ‘Educator' and ‘Supporter’ roles of your IDPs group Attribute 'MyIDPGroups' to your Umbraco ‘Teachers’ and 'SupportStaff’ as shown in image below.

For e.g.: You can map your IdPs ‘Educator' and ‘Supporter’ roles of your IDPs group Attribute 'MyIDPGroups' to your Umbraco ‘Teachers’ and 'SupportStaff’ as shown in image below.

- How Domain Restriction Works

This feature can be used to restrict user access to the application based on the domain of their mapped “Email“ Attribute.

You can provide multiple domains to restrict by entering a domain values separated by comma(,).

Now, for eg. If you want to restrict the user access to ‘miniOrange’ (i.e. miniorange.com) then you can simply enable the restrict toggle button and enter miniorange.com in the input tag.

title: Login Settings
content:
# Login Settings

This tab provides you with the various login settings. This includes redirecting users to the specific/dynamic page after login. In addition to this, you can also redirect users to the public page of your site and put Button/Link to perform the SSO.

# 1. Redirect after Login and Logout

- You just need to enter the full URL of the page inside the Redirection Section of the Login Setup where you wanted the user to be redirected.
Login Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging in.
Logout Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging in.

You just need to enter the full URL of the page inside the Redirection Section of the Login Setup where you wanted the user to be redirected.

Login Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging in.

Logout Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging in.

# 2. Prior SSO Redirections

A] Auto Redirect to IDP
- On enabling this features, the unauthenticated users will be redirected to the default IDP. You can either configure URLs to be restricted or can make it public.

On enabling this features, the unauthenticated users will be redirected to the default IDP. You can either configure URLs to be restricted or can make it public.
- The public URLs will be whitelisted and other all URLs when triggered will be redirected to IDP and vice versa for the Restricted URLs.

The public URLs will be whitelisted and other all URLs when triggered will be redirected to IDP and vice versa for the Restricted URLs.

B] Modify SSO Request
- Using this feature, you can add additional queryparamaters to your SSO Request. For e.g : As shown in image below, the SSO Request will have an additional parameter as “&memberType=Admin“

# 3. Authentication Methods

- Using this feature you can store the user attributes in a different ways.

Using this feature you can store the user attributes in a different ways.
- We provide following ways for storing user attributes.
Session based login - Session based login is used to store the user attributes in particular session.
Header based login -Header based login helps to authenticate the user via windows authentication.
Forms Authentication - Forms Authentication can store the user attributes in different forms.

We provide following ways for storing user attributes.

Session based login - Session based login is used to store the user attributes in particular session.

Header based login -Header based login helps to authenticate the user via windows authentication.

Forms Authentication - Forms Authentication can store the user attributes in different forms.

# 4. Custom Certificate

- Using this feature you can upload self signed custom certificate.

Using this feature you can upload self signed custom certificate.
- You will be required to provide your Private key in .pfx and Public key in .crt format. Enter your certificate password in plain-text, leave it empty if there is no password.

You will be required to provide your Private key in .pfx and Public key in .crt format. Enter your certificate password in plain-text, leave it empty if there is no password.

# 5. Custom URL'S

- This feature is used to customize the Login and Logout url's. SSO Login and Logout will get intiated using the custom login url and custom logout url respectively.

title: Integration Code
content:
# Integration Code

- After completing the SSO flow, user attributes received from the IdP are stored in the Browser Sessions under the Attribute Name configured in the plugin.

After completing the SSO flow, user attributes received from the IdP are stored in the Browser Sessions under the Attribute Name configured in the plugin.
- To access these sessions, you need to add some custom code in your application. With these custom attributes you can allow the user to get logged in to your application.

To access these sessions, you need to add some custom code in your application. With these custom attributes you can allow the user to get logged in to your application.
- You can find the code in the Integration Code section of the Login Setting tab.In this you will find code in two modes session variables and user claims according to your need select the mode and language. then Just paste the code where you want to access the sessions.

You can find the code in the Integration Code section of the Login Setting tab.In this you will find code in two modes session variables and user claims according to your need select the mode and language. then Just paste the code where you want to access the sessions.

title: Overview
content:
# DNN SAML Handbook

# About miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) Plugin –

- miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin enables seamless SSO login into your DNN Sites via authentication through any SAML 2.0 compliant identity providers.

miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin enables seamless SSO login into your DNN Sites via authentication through any SAML 2.0 compliant identity providers.
- This means, once you authenticate or log in via your identity provider, you also log into your DNN sites without manually having to re-enter your credentials.

This means, once you authenticate or log in via your identity provider, you also log into your DNN sites without manually having to re-enter your credentials.
- In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple Service Providers without the hassle of maintaining or remembering multiple credentials for multiple services.

In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple Service Providers without the hassle of maintaining or remembering multiple credentials for multiple services.
- The DNN SAML SSO Plugin supports all major IdPs – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML-compliant identity providers.

The DNN SAML SSO Plugin supports all major IdPs – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML-compliant identity providers.

- In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple Service Providers without the hassle of maintaining or remembering multiple credentials for multiple services.

In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple Service Providers without the hassle of maintaining or remembering multiple credentials for multiple services.
- The DNN SAML SSO Plugin supports all major IdPs – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML-compliant identity providers.

The DNN SAML SSO Plugin supports all major IdPs – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML-compliant identity providers.

title: Key Features
content:
# Key Features of miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) Plugin –

- Single Set of Credentials - The DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin enables you to use the same set of credentials used for logging in to your IdP to log in to your DNN sites as well such that once you sign into your IdP, you also sign-in into your DNN sites.

Single Set of Credentials - The DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin enables you to use the same set of credentials used for logging in to your IdP to log in to your DNN sites as well such that once you sign into your IdP, you also sign-in into your DNN sites.
- Auto-Create Users - We provide the feature to Auto-create users on your DNN Site and map their basic attribute values after authenticating with the identity provider.

Auto-Create Users - We provide the feature to Auto-create users on your DNN Site and map their basic attribute values after authenticating with the identity provider.
- Protect Complete Site - Protect your complete site behind the SSO by enforcing users to access your site only after they authenticate via their IdP for the SSO.

Protect Complete Site - Protect your complete site behind the SSO by enforcing users to access your site only after they authenticate via their IdP for the SSO.
- Login Widgets/Buttons/Shortcodes - Add a link or button anywhere on your DNN site to allow SSO / authentication via your identity provider to login into your DNN site.

Login Widgets/Buttons/Shortcodes - Add a link or button anywhere on your DNN site to allow SSO / authentication via your identity provider to login into your DNN site.
- Attribute & Role Mapping - Sync/Map user profile attributes from IDP to DNN site user profile fields, and assign roles based on user’s groups in your IDP.

Attribute & Role Mapping - Sync/Map user profile attributes from IDP to DNN site user profile fields, and assign roles based on user’s groups in your IDP.
- Single Logout - Terminate the user's SSO Session on the DNN application as well as your identity provider (IdP) when the user logs out of your DNN Site (SP).

Single Logout - Terminate the user's SSO Session on the DNN application as well as your identity provider (IdP) when the user logs out of your DNN Site (SP).
- Federation Support - Enables you to add the option to allow your users to SSO into your DNN site using their identities stored in the Federated identity providers.

Federation Support - Enables you to add the option to allow your users to SSO into your DNN site using their identities stored in the Federated identity providers.
- Domain Restriction - Allows you to make login to your site if the user is from the registered domains.

Domain Restriction - Allows you to make login to your site if the user is from the registered domains.

title: Download & Installation
content:
# Download and Installation

# Pre-requisites for the plugin:–

- Recommended DNN Version 8.0 & above, if you have any legacy version you can let us know we do have the support for them.

# How to download the DNN SAML Single Sign-on Module?

- You can install the DNN SAML SP plugin by following 2 ways:-
- DNN Store

You can Search for SAML SSO or visit this [LINK] to order the product.

Click on Add to Cart and fill in the required information and then you can move to My Accounts ⇒ Downloadable Products to download the plugin install.zip file.

DNN Store
- You can Search for SAML SSO or visit this [LINK] to order the product.

- Click on Add to Cart and fill in the required information and then you can move to My Accounts ⇒ Downloadable Products to download the plugin install.zip file.
- miniOrange marketplace

miniOrange marketplace
- Please visit the following [LINK] to directly download the DNN SAML Single Sign-on module.

# How to install the DNN SAML Single Sign-on Module?

Add extension on DNN page:
- Login into your DNN Site click on Settings Icon ⇒ Extensions => Install Extension, and upload the DNN_SAML_SSO_Install.zip file.

Add module on DNN page:
- Open any of the pages on your DNN site (Edit mode) and Click on Add Module.

Open any of the pages on your DNN site (Edit mode) and Click on Add Module.

- Search for DNNSAMLSSO and click on DNNSAMLSSO. Drag and drop the module on the page where you want.

Search for DNNSAMLSSO and click on DNNSAMLSSO. Drag and drop the module on the page where you want.

- You have finished with the Installation of the module on your DNN site.

You have finished with the Installation of the module on your DNN site.

title: How to Configure the Plugin
content:
# How to Configure the Plugin?

The miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin converts your DNN site into a SAML-compliant Service Provider, thereby generating the necessary details that are required for the metadata.

To configure the plugin you need to follow the steps given below:
- Upload SP Metadata in IdP - First, you have to create an SSO application at your identity provider site by providing the details about your DNN site from the Service Provider Section on the plugin dashboard. This in turn will generate the metadata of your identity provider, generally in the form of a URL or a downloadable XML file.

Upload SP Metadata in IdP - First, you have to create an SSO application at your identity provider site by providing the details about your DNN site from the Service Provider Section on the plugin dashboard. This in turn will generate the metadata of your identity provider, generally in the form of a URL or a downloadable XML file.
- Upload IdP Metadata in the plugin - Configure your miniOrange DNN SAML SSO Plugin, by uploading the metadata by clicking the upload metadata button in the identity provider Section of the Plugin from your identity provider. Once these 2 steps are over, the connection between your IdP and DNN site (SP) will be complete.

Upload IdP Metadata in the plugin - Configure your miniOrange DNN SAML SSO Plugin, by uploading the metadata by clicking the upload metadata button in the identity provider Section of the Plugin from your identity provider. Once these 2 steps are over, the connection between your IdP and DNN site (SP) will be complete.
- Test Configuration - Once you have successfully configured the identity provider click on the Test Configuration button to check if your SSO is working correctly.

Test Configuration - Once you have successfully configured the identity provider click on the Test Configuration button to check if your SSO is working correctly.
- Login Settings - This tab helps you to initiate SSO with your DNN site in different ways by redirecting users to specific/dynamic pages before login and after login.

Login Settings - This tab helps you to initiate SSO with your DNN site in different ways by redirecting users to specific/dynamic pages before login and after login.
- Attribute Mapping (Optional) - Attributes are user details stored in your identity provider. Every time when your user SSO into the DNN Site these attributes will be automatically mapped to your DNN user profile.

Attribute Mapping (Optional) - Attributes are user details stored in your identity provider. Every time when your user SSO into the DNN Site these attributes will be automatically mapped to your DNN user profile.
- Role Mapping (Optional) - Role Mapping is created to assign roles to users based on their SAML attributes. Through this, the particular role will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions when logging into the DNN site via SSO.

Role Mapping (Optional) - Role Mapping is created to assign roles to users based on their SAML attributes. Through this, the particular role will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions when logging into the DNN site via SSO.

Once the configuration is complete you will be redirected to your identity provider login when you initiate SSO login from your DNN site. After entering the IDP credentials the user will be logged into the DNN site (service provider) successfully establishing a secure Single Sign On Login.

title: Service Provider Metadata And Endpoints
content:
# Service Provider Metadata

For configuring the DNN Site on your IdP, you have three options:
- Metadata URL - The Metadata URL provides the DNN Site SAML Metadata information that can be used to configure the application in the identity provider (IdP) as an service provider (SP) in one go.

Metadata URL - The Metadata URL provides the DNN Site SAML Metadata information that can be used to configure the application in the identity provider (IdP) as an service provider (SP) in one go.
- Metadata XML - This file contains all the information about the SP in XML format. If the identity provider (IdP) supports importing the metadata from a file, then you can configure the application on your IdP in minutes by just uploading this metadata file.

Metadata XML - This file contains all the information about the SP in XML format. If the identity provider (IdP) supports importing the metadata from a file, then you can configure the application on your IdP in minutes by just uploading this metadata file.
- Configure IDP manually - You have the option of configuring your IdP manually using the SP URLs displayed in the Service Provider Settings tab. You will need to copy and paste the required URLs from the table into your IDP SAML Configuration to add the application as a SAML service provider (SP).

Configure IDP manually - You have the option of configuring your IdP manually using the SP URLs displayed in the Service Provider Settings tab. You will need to copy and paste the required URLs from the table into your IDP SAML Configuration to add the application as a SAML service provider (SP).

# Service Provider Endpoints

You are also provided the option to change your SP Base URL or SP-Entity ID. You just have to provide a new SP-BASE URL and click on Change. It will automatically change the corresponding credentials.

Note: Changing the SP Base URL and SP-Entity ID might break the already configured SSO as both the values need to be exactly the same in the application in IdP.

Note: This option is present in the Premium and Enterprise.

title: Service Provider Setup
content:
# Service Provider Setup

You can upload your identity provider's metadata in two ways:
- Uploading Metadata
You can upload your IdP metadata by clicking on the Upload IDP Metadata which provides you two options:

You can upload the XML file of your identity provider SAML 2.0 metadata.

You can provide us the link to the metadata of your identity provider.

Note: If the identity provider (IdP) metadata is changed you will be again required to provide us with the changes.

Uploading Metadata

You can upload your IdP metadata by clicking on the Upload IDP Metadata which provides you two options:
- You can upload the XML file of your identity provider SAML 2.0 metadata.

You can upload the XML file of your identity provider SAML 2.0 metadata.
- You can provide us the link to the metadata of your identity provider.

You can provide us the link to the metadata of your identity provider.

Note: If the identity provider (IdP) metadata is changed you will be again required to provide us with the changes.
- Manual Configuration
You can manually provide your IdP credentials where you need to provide the required settings and save them.

identity provider Name

IdP Entity ID or Issuer

SAML Login URL (The URL where SAML request needs to be posted not the login URL)

X.509 Certificate from the IDP

Manual Configuration

You can manually provide your IdP credentials where you need to provide the required settings and save them.
- identity provider Name

identity provider Name
- IdP Entity ID or Issuer

IdP Entity ID or Issuer
- SAML Login URL (The URL where SAML request needs to be posted not the login URL)

SAML Login URL (The URL where SAML request needs to be posted not the login URL)
- X.509 Certificate from the IDP

X.509 Certificate from the IDP

Test Configuration: After you provide your IdP’s metadata URL, you Save it and go to Test Configuration. There a new window will open which will display either of the following configuration status:-
- Configuration successful – with user attributes.

Configuration successful – with user attributes.
- Error message – if any configuration error is sent by IdP.

Error message – if any configuration error is sent by IdP.

When you are configuring your IdP, you will be given two options to send your SAML request in the Sign SSO & SLO Requests option.

Enabling these settings adds another layer of security to your SSO process as the SSO and SLO requests will be digitally signed using the default signing and encryption certificate present in the plugin. You can also use your own custom certificate for this instead.

Note: This option is present in the Premium and Enterprise.

You can select any of these options to send your SAML Request if your IDP supports the selected methods.
- HTTP-Post binding type
- HTTP-Redirect binding type

While configuring, it also provides the feature to add a Single Logout URL. But, this feature will only work if your IDP supports Single logout. Here also you can select the option of binding type to send your request.

Note: This option is present in the Premium and Enterprise.

title: Attribute & Role Mapping
content:
# Attribute & Role Mapping

It is the on-the-fly assignment of specific attributes/groups to your users as they are present in your IdP. When the user performs the SSO, the IDP sends over some attributes like NameID, Email, etc. which are then used to assign the users with specific functionalities like access or restrict the resources. The Attribute / Role Mapping tab allows you to enable these certain property-specific functionalities for your users during SSO.

This section contains the following 3 sections:

# 1. Attribute Mapping

Attributes are the user details that are stored in your identity provider. These attributes include Username, Email, First Name, Last Name, Group/Role, Display Name, etc. The Attribute Mapping feature helps you to map these user attributes sent by the IDP to the DNN user attributes.
- Every time your users SSO into your DNN site, these attributes will be automatically mapped to your DNN’s user profile.

Every time your users SSO into your DNN site, these attributes will be automatically mapped to your DNN’s user profile.
- If any existing user performs the SSO, then their application account will be fetched and their profile will be updated based on attributes received from the IDP.

If any existing user performs the SSO, then their application account will be fetched and their profile will be updated based on attributes received from the IDP.
- By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.

By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.
- You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.

You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.
- The Group/Role field can be used as a group transformation attribute. You can map the Group/Role field to the attribute name in which IDP is sending the user's information.

The Group/Role field can be used as a group transformation attribute. You can map the Group/Role field to the attribute name in which IDP is sending the user's information.
- Depending on the value of the Group attribute, you can assign single or multiple roles to the users. Custom roles are also supported for the mapping. Please refer to the role mapping section for more information.

Depending on the value of the Group attribute, you can assign single or multiple roles to the users. Custom roles are also supported for the mapping. Please refer to the role mapping section for more information.

Map Custom Attributes
- It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to DNN users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.

It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to DNN users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.
- Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no., City, State, and Department etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.

Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no., City, State, and Department etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.
- For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the identity provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the identity provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

# 2. Role Mapping

- This feature can be used to assign different roles to the users based on their SAML attributes. The particular roles will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions while logging into DNN via Single Sign-On.

This feature can be used to assign different roles to the users based on their SAML attributes. The particular roles will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions while logging into DNN via Single Sign-On.
- This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IdP attribute Group values.

This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IdP attribute Group values.
- Before enabling this setting, please make sure you’ve configured the attribute name in the Group/Role field of the Attribute Mapping section.

Before enabling this setting, please make sure you’ve configured the attribute name in the Group/Role field of the Attribute Mapping section.
- If the admin wants users of a particular IDP group(s) to be restricted from logging in to the site, this feature can be enabled by providing the group value(s).

If the admin wants users of a particular IDP group(s) to be restricted from logging in to the site, this feature can be enabled by providing the group value(s).
- This feature can be used where we have a group of students with Off-Campus Registration. They have been assigned a IDP group ‘Outside Users’ and the admin does not want those users to access the site.

This feature can be used where we have a group of students with Off-Campus Registration. They have been assigned a IDP group ‘Outside Users’ and the admin does not want those users to access the site.

# 3. Domain Restriction

This feature can be used to restrict/allow the user access to the application based on the domain of their email address.
- You can provide multiple domains to restrict by entering domain values separated by comma(,).

It has the following 2 ways to use this feature:
- Allow users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then only the users of specified domains will be allowed to log in or register.

Allow users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then only the users of specified domains will be allowed to log in or register.
- Deny users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then users of specified domains will be restricted from login in. The remaining users will be allowed to log in.

Deny users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then users of specified domains will be restricted from login in. The remaining users will be allowed to log in.
- Now, for eg. If you want users of ‘miniOrange’ (i.e. miniorange.com) to not log in to your site, then you can simply enter miniorange.com in the input tag and select the radio button “Deny users to login with specified domains”.

Now, for eg. If you want users of ‘miniOrange’ (i.e. miniorange.com) to not log in to your site, then you can simply enter miniorange.com in the input tag and select the radio button “Deny users to login with specified domains”.

title: Redirection And SSO Settings
content:
# Redirection & SSO Settings

This feature allows you to the various login settings. This includes redirecting users to the specific/dynamic page before login and after login, Auto creates users if they are not present on your DNN site, and Force authentication which will redirect the user to IdP forcefully if no user session is found.

# Auto Creation

Users who are authenticated from the identity provider side but are not present in the DNN site will be created automatically with the profile attributes mapped:

# Redirect after Login and Logout:

You just need to enter the full URL of the page inside the Redirection Section of the Login Setup where you wanted the user to be redirected.
- Login Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging in.

Login Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging in.
- Logout Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging out.

Logout Endpoint URL - Enter the URL of the page where you want to get redirected after logging out.

# Page Restriction / Force Authentication

This feature allows you to directly redirect the user to your identity provider if no logged-in session is found.

title: Overview
content:
# DNN SAML IDP Handbook

# About miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 IDP Module– –

- miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 IDP module enables seamless SSO login into any SAML 2.0 compliant web applications via authentication through your DNN as SAML identity provider (IDP).

miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 IDP module enables seamless SSO login into any SAML 2.0 compliant web applications via authentication through your DNN as SAML identity provider (IDP).
- This means once you authenticate or log in via your DNN identity provider (IDP), you also log into the service provider applications without manually having to re-enter your credentials.

This means once you authenticate or log in via your DNN identity provider (IDP), you also log into the service provider applications without manually having to re-enter your credentials.
- In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple service providers (SP) without the hassle of maintaining or remembering your IDP credentials for multiple services.

In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple service providers (SP) without the hassle of maintaining or remembering your IDP credentials for multiple services.
- The DNN SAML IDP Module supports all major SPs – Tableau Online, Tableau Server, Zoom, Zoho, Cognito, Moodle, FreshDesk, NextCloud, Canvas LMS, Absorb LMS, Talent LMS and other SAML-compliant identity providers

The DNN SAML IDP Module supports all major SPs – Tableau Online, Tableau Server, Zoom, Zoho, Cognito, Moodle, FreshDesk, NextCloud, Canvas LMS, Absorb LMS, Talent LMS and other SAML-compliant identity providers

title: Key Features
content:
# Key Features of miniOrange DNN SAML 2.0 IDP Module –

- Support for SAML Service Provider - DNN SAML IDP supports any SAML 2.0 Service Provider. Log in to any SAML-compliant service providers using your DNN site credentials.

Support for SAML Service Provider - DNN SAML IDP supports any SAML 2.0 Service Provider. Log in to any SAML-compliant service providers using your DNN site credentials.
- Supports Signed & Encrypted Assertions - Make user login more secure by signing and encrypting responses to service provider.

Supports Signed & Encrypted Assertions - Make user login more secure by signing and encrypting responses to service provider.
- IDP-initiated SSO - Seamlessly initiate Single Sign-On to login into service providers from DNN application or site.

IDP-initiated SSO - Seamlessly initiate Single Sign-On to login into service providers from DNN application or site.
- SAML Single Logout - Allows a user to log out from all service providers' sessions established via SAML SSO by initiating the logout process once.

SAML Single Logout - Allows a user to log out from all service providers' sessions established via SAML SSO by initiating the logout process once.
- Attribute Mapping - Use the Attribute Mapping feature to send DNN user profile attributes to your service provider attributes.

Attribute Mapping - Use the Attribute Mapping feature to send DNN user profile attributes to your service provider attributes.
- Role Mapping - Use the Role Mapping feature to send roles assigned to users from your DNN site to your service provider.

Role Mapping - Use the Role Mapping feature to send roles assigned to users from your DNN site to your service provider.
- Custom Certificate - Add your own custom X.509 Certificate for sending signed responses and verification of signed Requests.

Custom Certificate - Add your own custom X.509 Certificate for sending signed responses and verification of signed Requests.

title: How to Install & Upgrade to Paid Version
content:
# How to install the paid version of the module?

Follow the steps mentioned below to download the paid module:
- Click here to login into miniOrange/Xecurify dashboard.

Click here to login into miniOrange/Xecurify dashboard.
- Go to the License - Manage License menu from the bottom left corner.

Go to the License - Manage License menu from the bottom left corner.
- Open the tab Releases & Downloads tab and download the module from the link given there.

Open the tab Releases & Downloads tab and download the module from the link given there.
- Click on the View License Key button to get your license key which will be used to install and activate the module on your site.

Click on the View License Key button to get your license key which will be used to install and activate the module on your site.

Log in to your DNN site or application using an admin account.
- Follow the instructions, to install the module from the setup guide.

Follow the instructions, to install the module from the setup guide.
- After installing the module, log in to the module using your miniOrange credentials.

After installing the module, log in to the module using your miniOrange credentials.
- Enter the license key you received from your miniOrange/Xecurify dashboard, accept the terms and conditions, and click Activate License.

Enter the license key you received from your miniOrange/Xecurify dashboard, accept the terms and conditions, and click Activate License.

- Enter the license key you received from your miniOrange/Xecurify dashboard, accept the terms and conditions, and click Activate License.

title: How to Configure the Plugin
content:
# How to Configure the Plugin?

The miniOrange DNN SAML IDP module converts your DNN application into a SAML-compliant identity provider, thereby generating the necessary details that are required for the metadata.

To configure the module you need to follow the steps given below:
- Select the Service Provider - Select your desired service provider from the list of tested service providers in the Select your Service Provider section.

Select the Service Provider - Select your desired service provider from the list of tested service providers in the Select your Service Provider section.
- Service-Provider Specific Settings - The free Version of the DNN SAML IDP module is configured to adjust module features, according to the selected service provider requirements, i.e. for example a service provider requires a certain feature that is available in the paid version, then it will be activated for that selected service provider only.

Service-Provider Specific Settings - The free Version of the DNN SAML IDP module is configured to adjust module features, according to the selected service provider requirements, i.e. for example a service provider requires a certain feature that is available in the paid version, then it will be activated for that selected service provider only.
- Upload SP Metadata in module - Configure your miniOrange DNN SAML IDP module, by uploading the metadata by clicking the upload metadata button in the SP Configuration section of the module from your service provider.

Upload SP Metadata in module - Configure your miniOrange DNN SAML IDP module, by uploading the metadata by clicking the upload metadata button in the SP Configuration section of the module from your service provider.
- Upload Module Metadata in the Service Provider - Provide the meta details of your identity provider from the IDP Metadata section on the module dashboard. You can get the metadata of your identity provider, generally, in the form of a URL or a downloadable XML file. Once these 2 steps are over, the connection between DNN SAML IDP and your application will be complete.

Upload Module Metadata in the Service Provider - Provide the meta details of your identity provider from the IDP Metadata section on the module dashboard. You can get the metadata of your identity provider, generally, in the form of a URL or a downloadable XML file. Once these 2 steps are over, the connection between DNN SAML IDP and your application will be complete.
- Attribute Mapping - Attributes are user details stored in your DNN application which is now your identity provider application. Every time when your users SSO into the service provider application these attributes will be automatically sent from your DNN application and mapped to your service provider user attributes.

Attribute Mapping - Attributes are user details stored in your DNN application which is now your identity provider application. Every time when your users SSO into the service provider application these attributes will be automatically sent from your DNN application and mapped to your service provider user attributes.

Once the configuration is complete you will be redirected to your DNN application (IDP) for login when you initiate SSO login from your application (SP). After entering the DNN user credentials the user will be logged into the application (SP) successfully establishing a secure login via Single Sign-On (SSO).

Note: - The feature mentioned above is directed to the free version only, as it has no requirement for the paid version.

title: Identity Provider Metadata
content:
# Identity Provider Metadata

For configuring your application (SP) with your DNN application metadata, you have three options:
- Metadata URL
The metadata URL provided by DNN SAML 2.0 IDP Module contains your DNN application’s SAML metadata information that can be used to configure the application in the SP in one go. You can provide the metadata URL to your service provider. The provided metadata URL will be in this format:
<BASE_URL>/DesktopModules/idp/API/saml/IDPMetadata/

Metadata URL

The metadata URL provided by DNN SAML 2.0 IDP Module contains your DNN application’s SAML metadata information that can be used to configure the application in the SP in one go. You can provide the metadata URL to your service provider. The provided metadata URL will be in this format:

```
<BASE_URL>/DesktopModules/idp/API/saml/IDPMetadata/
```

- Metadata XML
This file provided by DNN SAML IDP module contains all the information about your DNN application (IDP) in XML format. If the SP supports importing the metadata from a file, then you can configure the application on your SP in minutes by just uploading this metadata file.
You can download the module XML metadata and upload it to your Service Provider.

Metadata XML

This file provided by DNN SAML IDP module contains all the information about your DNN application (IDP) in XML format. If the SP supports importing the metadata from a file, then you can configure the application on your SP in minutes by just uploading this metadata file.
You can download the module XML metadata and upload it to your Service Provider.

- Configure Service Provider Manually
You have the option of configuring your SP manually using the IDP URLs displayed in the Identity Provider Metadata section. You will need to copy and paste the required URLs provided in the “Identity Provider Metadata” section into your SP SAML Configuration where you need to provide the required settings and save them to add the DNN application as a SAML IDP.

Configure Service Provider Manually

You have the option of configuring your SP manually using the IDP URLs displayed in the Identity Provider Metadata section. You will need to copy and paste the required URLs provided in the “Identity Provider Metadata” section into your SP SAML Configuration where you need to provide the required settings and save them to add the DNN application as a SAML IDP.

title: DNN SAML IDP Endpoints
content:
# DNN SAML IDP Endpoints

You can provide the following information to your service provider:
- IDP Entity ID or Issuer

```
https://example.com/DesktopModules/MVC/modnnsamlidp
```
- Single Sign-On URL (The URL where SAML login request will be posted.)

```
https://example.com/DesktopModules/idp/API/saml/login
```
- IDP Initiated SSO URL

```
https://example.com/DesktopModules/idp/API/saml/idpinitiatedlogin
```
- SAML SLO URL (The URL where SAML logout request will be posted.)

```
https://example.com/DesktopModules/idp/API/saml/logout
```
- X.509 Certificate (If a Signed Response or Signed Assertion needs to be posted from IDP)

title: Service Provider Setup
content:
# Service Provider Setup

- Uploading SP Metadata
You can upload your SP metadata by clicking on the Upload SP Metadata button which provides you with two options in the Service Provider Settings section:

Choose the .xml file containing the metadata from your device and upload it.

If your service provider provides a metadata endpoint, then you can enter the metadata URL of your service provider and click on Fetch Metadata.

Uploading SP Metadata

You can upload your SP metadata by clicking on the Upload SP Metadata button which provides you with two options in the Service Provider Settings section:
- Choose the .xml file containing the metadata from your device and upload it.

- If your service provider provides a metadata endpoint, then you can enter the metadata URL of your service provider and click on Fetch Metadata.

- Manual Configuration
You can manually provide your SP metadata URLs in the Service Provider Settings section.

SP Entity ID or Issuer
Audience URI (Optional)
ACS URL (The URL where SAML response needs to be posted not the login URL)
X.509 Certificate from the SP (If a Signed Login/Logout Request will be posted from SP)

Manual Configuration

You can manually provide your SP metadata URLs in the Service Provider Settings section.
- SP Entity ID or Issuer
- Audience URI (Optional)
- ACS URL (The URL where SAML response needs to be posted not the login URL)
- X.509 Certificate from the SP (If a Signed Login/Logout Request will be posted from SP)

When you are configuring the DNN SAML 2.0 IDP Module, you will be given the option to get your SAML request in the Signed Requests option, and to post the SAML response with the “Encrypted Assertion” or/and “Signed Assertion”, or/and “Signed Response”.

Enabling these settings adds another layer of security to your SSO process as the Response and Assertion will be digitally signed using the default signing and encryption certificate present in the module.

Note: This option is present in the Premium and Enterprise.

title: Attribute & Role Mapping
content:
# Attribute & Role Mapping

It is the on-the-fly assignment of specific attributes/roles to your users as they are present in your IDP. When the user performs the SSO, the IDP sends over some attributes like NameID, Email, etc. which are then used to assign the users with specific functionalities like access or restrict the resources. The Attribute/Role Mapping section allows you to enable these certain property-specific functionalities for your users during SSO.

This section contains the following 3 sections:

# 1. Attribute Mapping

Attributes are the user details that are stored in your identity provider. These attributes include Username, Email, First Name, Last Name, Group/Role, Display Name, etc. The Attribute Mapping feature helps you to map these DNN user attributes sent by the IDP to the user attributes on SP.
- Every time a user SSO into your application, these DNN user attributes will be automatically mapped to your application’s user profile.

Every time a user SSO into your application, these DNN user attributes will be automatically mapped to your application’s user profile.
- If any existing user performs the SSO, then their application account will be fetched and their profile will be updated based on attributes received from the IDP.

If any existing user performs the SSO, then their application account will be fetched and their profile will be updated based on attributes received from the IDP.
- By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.

By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.
- You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.

You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.
- The Group/Role field can be used as a group transformation attribute. You can map the Group/Role field to the attribute name in which IDP is sending the DNN user’s Information.

The Group/Role field can be used as a group transformation attribute. You can map the Group/Role field to the attribute name in which IDP is sending the DNN user’s Information.
- Depending on the value of the Group attribute, you can assign single or multiple roles to the users. Custom roles are also supported for the mapping. Please refer to the role mapping section for more information.

Depending on the value of the Group attribute, you can assign single or multiple roles to the users. Custom roles are also supported for the mapping. Please refer to the role mapping section for more information.

Map Custom Attributes
- It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to the DNN users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.

It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to the DNN users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.
- Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no., City, State, or Department, etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.

Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no., City, State, or Department, etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.
- For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the identity provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the identity provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

# 2. Role Mapping

- This feature can be used to assign different roles to the users based on their SAML attributes. The DNN user roles will be applied to your users once they meet the specified conditions while logging into your service provider application via Single Sign-On.

This feature can be used to assign different roles to the users based on their SAML attributes. The DNN user roles will be applied to your users once they meet the specified conditions while logging into your service provider application via Single Sign-On.
- This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IDP attribute Group values.

This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IDP attribute Group values.
- Before enabling this setting, please make sure you’ve configured the attribute name in the Group/Role field of the Attribute Mapping section.

Before enabling this setting, please make sure you’ve configured the attribute name in the Group/Role field of the Attribute Mapping section.

- If the admin wants users of a particular IDP group(s) to be restricted from logging in to the site, this feature can be enabled by providing the group value(s).

If the admin wants users of a particular IDP group(s) to be restricted from logging in to the site, this feature can be enabled by providing the group value(s).
- This feature can be used where we have a group of students with Off-Campus Registration. They have been assigned an IDP group Outside Users and the admin does not want those users to access the site.

This feature can be used where we have a group of students with Off-Campus Registration. They have been assigned an IDP group Outside Users and the admin does not want those users to access the site.

title: Overview
content:
# nopCommerce SAML Handbook

# About miniOrange nopCommerce SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO) Plugin –

- miniOrange nopCommerce SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO) plugin enables seamless SSO login into your nopCommerce sites via authentication through any SAML 2.0 compliant identity providers.

miniOrange nopCommerce SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO) plugin enables seamless SSO login into your nopCommerce sites via authentication through any SAML 2.0 compliant identity providers.
- This means, once you authenticate or log in via your identity provider, you also log into your nopCommerce sites or stores without manually having to re-enter your credentials.

This means, once you authenticate or log in via your identity provider, you also log into your nopCommerce sites or stores without manually having to re-enter your credentials.
- In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple Service Providers without the hassle of maintaining or remembering multiple credentials for multiple services.

In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple Service Providers without the hassle of maintaining or remembering multiple credentials for multiple services.
- The nopCommerce SAML SSO Plugin supports all major IdPs – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML-compliant identity providers.

The nopCommerce SAML SSO Plugin supports all major IdPs – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML-compliant identity providers.

# How to install the trial version of the plugin?

Setup Guide

title: Key Features
content:
# Key Features of miniOrange nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) Plugin –

- Single Set of Credentials - The nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) plugin enables you to use the same set of credentials used for logging in to your IdP to log in to your nopCommerce sites as well such that once you sign into your IdP, you also sign-in into your nopCommerce stores or sites.

Single Set of Credentials - The nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) plugin enables you to use the same set of credentials used for logging in to your IdP to log in to your nopCommerce sites as well such that once you sign into your IdP, you also sign-in into your nopCommerce stores or sites.
- Auto-Create Users - We provide the feature to Auto-create users on your nopCommerce site and map their basic attribute values after authenticating with the identity provider.

Auto-Create Users - We provide the feature to Auto-create users on your nopCommerce site and map their basic attribute values after authenticating with the identity provider.
- Restrict pages with SSO Login - Restrict your complete site to only logged in users by enforcing users to authenticate first via their IdP.

Restrict pages with SSO Login - Restrict your complete site to only logged in users by enforcing users to authenticate first via their IdP.
- Login Widgets/Buttons/Shortcodes - Add a link or button anywhere on your nopCommerce site to allow SSO / authentication via your identity provider to login into your nopCommerce site.

Login Widgets/Buttons/Shortcodes - Add a link or button anywhere on your nopCommerce site to allow SSO / authentication via your identity provider to login into your nopCommerce site.
- Attribute & Role Mapping - Sync/Map user profile attributes from IDP to nopCommerce site user profile fields, and assign roles based on user’s groups in your IDP.

Attribute & Role Mapping - Sync/Map user profile attributes from IDP to nopCommerce site user profile fields, and assign roles based on user’s groups in your IDP.
- Single Logout - Terminate the user's SSO Session on the nopCommerce application as well as your identity provider (IdP) when the user logs out of your nopCommerce Site (SP).

Single Logout - Terminate the user's SSO Session on the nopCommerce application as well as your identity provider (IdP) when the user logs out of your nopCommerce Site (SP).
- Federation Support - Enables you to add the option to allow your users to SSO into your nopCommerce site or store using their identities stored in the Federated identity providers.

Federation Support - Enables you to add the option to allow your users to SSO into your nopCommerce site or store using their identities stored in the Federated identity providers.
- Domain Restriction - Allows you to make login to your site if the user is from the registered domains.

Domain Restriction - Allows you to make login to your site if the user is from the registered domains.

title: Download & Installation
content:
# Download and Installation

# Pre-requisites for the plugin:–

- Recommended nopCommerce Version 4.2 & above, if you have any legacy version you can let us know we do have the support for them.

# How to download the nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-on Module?

- You can install the nopCommerce SAML SP plugin by following 2 ways:-
- nopCommerce Store

You can search for SAML or visit this [LINK] to order the product.

Click on GET EXTENSION and if already logged into the marketplace you will get the plugin xxxxx.zip file.

nopCommerce Store
- You can search for SAML or visit this [LINK] to order the product.

- Click on GET EXTENSION and if already logged into the marketplace you will get the plugin xxxxx.zip file.
- miniOrange marketplace

miniOrange marketplace
- Please visit the following [LINK] to directly download the nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) module.

# How to install the nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-on plugin?

Add extension on nopCommerce page:
- Login into your nopCommerce Site click on Administration ⇒ Configuration => Local Plugins, and upload the xxxxx.zip file.

Login into your nopCommerce Site click on Administration ⇒ Configuration => Local Plugins, and upload the xxxxx.zip file.
- You can find the plugin in the plugins list and click on Install.

You can find the plugin in the plugins list and click on Install.
- You have finished with the installation of the plugin on your nopCommerce site.

You have finished with the installation of the plugin on your nopCommerce site.

title: How to Configure the Plugin
content:
# How to Configure the Plugin?

The miniOrange nopCommerce SAML Single Sign-On (SSO) plugin converts your nopCommerce site into a SAML-compliant Service Provider, thereby generating the necessary details that are required for the metadata.

To configure the plugin you need to follow the steps given below:
- Upload SP Metadata in IdP - First, you have to create an SSO application at your Identity Provider side using the metadata generated by the plugin from your nopCommerce site. This in turn will generate the metadata of your Identity Provider, generally in the form of a URL or a downloadable XML file.

Upload SP Metadata in IdP - First, you have to create an SSO application at your Identity Provider side using the metadata generated by the plugin from your nopCommerce site. This in turn will generate the metadata of your Identity Provider, generally in the form of a URL or a downloadable XML file.
- Upload IdP Metadata in the plugin - To configure miniOrange nopCommerce plugin, upload the metadata provided by your identity provider by clicking the upload metadata button in the Identity Provider Section of the Plugin. Once these 2 steps are over, the connection between your IdP and nopCommerce site (SP) will be completed.

Upload IdP Metadata in the plugin - To configure miniOrange nopCommerce plugin, upload the metadata provided by your identity provider by clicking the upload metadata button in the Identity Provider Section of the Plugin. Once these 2 steps are over, the connection between your IdP and nopCommerce site (SP) will be completed.
- Test Configuration - Once you have successfully configured the Identity Provider click on the Test Configuration button to check if your SSO is working correctly.

Test Configuration - Once you have successfully configured the Identity Provider click on the Test Configuration button to check if your SSO is working correctly.
- Attribute Mapping - Attributes are user details stored in your Identity Provider. Every time when your user SSO into the nopCommerce Site these attributes will be automatically mapped to your nopCommerce user profile.

Attribute Mapping - Attributes are user details stored in your Identity Provider. Every time when your user SSO into the nopCommerce Site these attributes will be automatically mapped to your nopCommerce user profile.
- Role Mapping (Optional) - Role Mapping is used to assign roles to users based on their SAML attributes. Through this, the particular role will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions when logging into the nopCommerce site via SSO.

Role Mapping (Optional) - Role Mapping is used to assign roles to users based on their SAML attributes. Through this, the particular role will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions when logging into the nopCommerce site via SSO.
- Redirection and SSO Link - This tab helps you to configure a “redirect url after login” i.e where the user will be redirected after login into your nopCommerce site. Also here you can find the SSO link of your nopCommerce site or store.

Redirection and SSO Link - This tab helps you to configure a “redirect url after login” i.e where the user will be redirected after login into your nopCommerce site. Also here you can find the SSO link of your nopCommerce site or store.

Once the configuration is complete, when you initiate SSO login from your nopCommerce site, you will be redirected to your Identity provider login. After entering the IDP credentials the user will be logged into the nopCommerce site (SP) successfully establishing a secure Single Sign On Login.

title: Service Provider Metadata
content:
# Service Provider Metadata

For configuring the nopCommerce site on your IdP, you have four options:
- Metadata URL - The Metadata URL provides the nopCommerce Site SAML Metadata information that can be used to configure the application in the IdP as an SP in one go.

Metadata URL - The Metadata URL provides the nopCommerce Site SAML Metadata information that can be used to configure the application in the IdP as an SP in one go.
- Metadata XML as file - This file contains all the information about the SP in XML format. If the IdP supports importing the metadata from a file, then you can configure the application on your IdP in minutes by just uploading this metadata file.

Metadata XML as file - This file contains all the information about the SP in XML format. If the IdP supports importing the metadata from a file, then you can configure the application on your IdP in minutes by just uploading this metadata file.
- Metadata XML as text - If your IDP supports to put metadata as text then you can use this option.

Metadata XML as text - If your IDP supports to put metadata as text then you can use this option.
- Configure IDP manually - You have the option of configuring your IdP manually using the SP URLs displayed in the “Service Provider Settings” tab. You will need to copy and paste the required URLs from the table into your IDP SAML Configuration to add the application as a SAML SP.

Configure IDP manually - You have the option of configuring your IdP manually using the SP URLs displayed in the “Service Provider Settings” tab. You will need to copy and paste the required URLs from the table into your IDP SAML Configuration to add the application as a SAML SP.

title: Service Provider Setup
content:
# Service Provider Setup

- Uploading Metadata
You can upload your IdP metadata by clicking on the Upload IDP Metadata which provides you two options:

You can upload your Identity Provider metadata using the XML file.

You can use the metadata URL of your Identity Provider to upload metadata.

Note: If the IdP metadata is changed you will be again required to provide us with the updated metadata.

Uploading Metadata

You can upload your IdP metadata by clicking on the Upload IDP Metadata which provides you two options:
- You can upload your Identity Provider metadata using the XML file.

You can upload your Identity Provider metadata using the XML file.
- You can use the metadata URL of your Identity Provider to upload metadata.

You can use the metadata URL of your Identity Provider to upload metadata.

Note: If the IdP metadata is changed you will be again required to provide us with the updated metadata.
- Manual Configuration
You can manually configure your IdP metadata where you need to have the following settings and save them.

identity provider name

IdP Entity ID or Issuer

SAML Login URL (The URL where SAML request needs to be posted not the login URL)

X.509 Certificate from the IDP

Manual Configuration

You can manually configure your IdP metadata where you need to have the following settings and save them.
- identity provider name

identity provider name
- IdP Entity ID or Issuer

IdP Entity ID or Issuer
- SAML Login URL (The URL where SAML request needs to be posted not the login URL)

SAML Login URL (The URL where SAML request needs to be posted not the login URL)
- X.509 Certificate from the IDP

X.509 Certificate from the IDP

# Auto Creation of Users

Users who are authenticated from the Identity Provider side but are not present in the nopCommerce site will be created automatically with the profile attributes mapped.

Test Configuration: After you configure your IdP’s metadata, you SAVE it and go to Test Configuration. There a new window will open which will display either of the following configuration status:-
- Configuration successful – with user attributes.

Configuration successful – with user attributes.
- Error message – if any configuration error is sent by IdP.

Error message – if any configuration error is sent by IdP.

When you are configuring your IdP, you will be given an option to send the signed SAML SSO and SLO Requests.

Enabling this option adds another layer of security to your SSO and SLO process as the SSO/SLO request will be digitally signed using the default signing and encryption certificate present in the plugin. You can also use your own custom certificate for this instead.

Note: This option is present in the Premium and Enterprise.

You can select any of these options to send your SAML Request if your IDP supports the selected methods.
- HTTP-Post binding type
- HTTP-Redirect binding type

While configuring, it also provides the feature to add a Single Logout URL. But, this feature will only work if your IDP supports Single logout. Here also you can select the option of binding type to send your request.

Note: This is present in all our plugins from the Premium plan onwards.

content:

You can upload your IdP metadata by clicking on the Upload IDP Metadata which provides you two options:

title: Attribute & Role Mapping
content:
# Attribute & Role Mapping

It is the on-the-fly assignment of specific attributes/groups to your users as they are present in your IdP. When the user performs the SSO, the IDP sends over some attributes like NameID, Email, etc. which are then used to assign the users with specific functionalities like access or restrict the resources. The Attribute / Role Mapping tab allows you to enable these certain property-specific functionalities for your users during SSO

This section contains the following 3 sections:

# 1. Attribute Mapping

Attributes are the user details that are stored in your identity provider. These attributes include Username, Email, First Name, Last Name, Group/Role, Display Name, etc. The Attribute Mapping feature helps you to map these user attributes sent by the IDP to the nopCommerce user attributes.
- Every time your users SSO into your nopCommerce site or store, these attributes will be automatically mapped to your nopCommerce's user profile.

Every time your users SSO into your nopCommerce site or store, these attributes will be automatically mapped to your nopCommerce's user profile.
- If any existing user performs the SSO, then their application account will be fetched and their profile will be updated based on attributes received from the IDP.

If any existing user performs the SSO, then their application account will be fetched and their profile will be updated based on attributes received from the IDP.
- By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.

By default, the Username and Email are the two basic attributes that are used for attribute mapping. Generally, the NameID value is what’s used for this purpose.
- You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.

You can choose and set attributes sent by the IDP to be mapped with attributes like FirstName and LastName.
- The Group/Role field can be used as a group transformation attribute. You can map the Group/Role field to the attribute name in which IDP is sending the user's information.

The Group/Role field can be used as a group transformation attribute. You can map the Group/Role field to the attribute name in which IDP is sending the user's information.
- Depending on the value of the Group attribute, you can assign single or multiple roles to the users. Custom roles are also supported for the mapping. Please refer to the role mapping section for more information.

Depending on the value of the Group attribute, you can assign single or multiple roles to the users. Custom roles are also supported for the mapping. Please refer to the role mapping section for more information.

Map Custom Attributes
- It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to nopCommerce users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.

It provides an additional feature to Map Custom Attributes to nopCommerce users. Using this feature you can map and access additional attributes received from the IDP in your application.
- Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no., City, State, and Department etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.

Suppose, you want to map attributes like Phone no., City, State, and Department etc., you will simply have to add these attributes in your IDP and set them up into your Custom attribute mapping to map with their equivalent attributes.
- For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the identity provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

For example, the image below shows the above attributes which are sent from the identity provider appropriately added and mapped to their equivalent attributes name.

# 2. Role Mapping

- This feature can be used to assign different roles to the users based on their SAML attributes. The particular roles will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions while logging into nopCommerce via Single Sign-On.

This feature can be used to assign different roles to the users based on their SAML attributes. The particular roles will be applied to users once they meet the specified conditions while logging into nopCommerce via Single Sign-On.
- This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IdP attribute Group values.

This feature allows you to provide user capabilities based on their IdP attribute Group values.
- If the admin wants users of a particular IDP group(s) to be restricted from logging in to the site, this feature can be enabled by providing the group value(s).

If the admin wants users of a particular IDP group(s) to be restricted from logging in to the site, this feature can be enabled by providing the group value(s).
- This feature can be used where we have a group of students with Off-Campus Registration. They have been assigned a IDP group ‘Outside Users’ and the admin does not want those users to access the site.

This feature can be used where we have a group of students with Off-Campus Registration. They have been assigned a IDP group ‘Outside Users’ and the admin does not want those users to access the site.

# 3. Domain Restriction

This feature can be used to restrict/allow the user access to the application based on the domain of their email address.
- You can provide multiple domains to restrict by entering domain values separated by comma(,).

It has the following 2 ways to use this feature:
- Allow users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then only the users of specified domains will be allowed to log in or register.

Allow users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then only the users of specified domains will be allowed to log in or register.
- Deny users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then users of specified domains will be restricted from login in. The remaining users will be allowed to log in.

Deny users to login with specified domains: If enable this feature then users of specified domains will be restricted from login in. The remaining users will be allowed to log in.

Now, for eg. If you want users of ‘miniOrange’ (i.e. miniorange.com) to not log in to your site, then you can simply enter miniorange.com in the input tag and select the radio button Deny users to login with specified domains.

# SSO Restriction based on Roles:

- Allow users with the selected role to login.

Allow users with the selected role to login.
- Deny users with the selected role to login.

Deny users with the selected role to login.

title: Overview
content:
# Umbraco SAML Handbook

# About miniOrange Umbraco SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) Plugin –

- miniOrange Umbraco SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin enables seamless SSO login into your Umbraco site via authentication through any SAML compliant identity provider.

miniOrange Umbraco SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) plugin enables seamless SSO login into your Umbraco site via authentication through any SAML compliant identity provider.
- In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple service providers without the hassle of maintaining or memorizing multiple credentials for multiple services.

In essence, you use just a single set of credentials for logging into multiple service providers without the hassle of maintaining or memorizing multiple credentials for multiple services.
- The Umbraco SAML 2.0 SSO plugin supports all major identity providers (IdPs) – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML compliant identity providers.

The Umbraco SAML 2.0 SSO plugin supports all major identity providers (IdPs) – ADFS, Azure AD, Azure B2C, Okta, Keycloak, Google Workspace, Salesforce, Office365, Shibboleth and other SAML compliant identity providers.

# How to install the trial version of the plugin?

Setup Guide

title: Key Features
content:
# Key Features of miniOrange SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) Plugin –

- Single Set of Credentials - The miniOrange SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) Plugin enables you to use the same set of credentials used for logging in to your IdP to log in to your Umbraco site as well. such that once you sign into your IdP, you also sign into Umbraco site.

Single Set of Credentials - The miniOrange SAML 2.0 Single Sign On (SSO) Plugin enables you to use the same set of credentials used for logging in to your IdP to log in to your Umbraco site as well. such that once you sign into your IdP, you also sign into Umbraco site.
- Auto-Create Users - We provide the feature to Auto create users on your Umbraco site and map their basic attribute values after authenticating with the Identity Provider.

Auto-Create Users - We provide the feature to Auto create users on your Umbraco site and map their basic attribute values after authenticating with the Identity Provider.
- Protect Complete Site - Protect your complete site behind the SSO by enforcing users to access your site only after they authenticate via their IdP for the SSO.

Protect Complete Site - Protect your complete site behind the SSO by enforcing users to access your site only after they authenticate via their IdP for the SSO.
- Attribute & Role Mapping - Sync/Map user profile attributes from IDP to Umbraco site user profile fields, and assign roles based on user’s groups in your IDP.

Attribute & Role Mapping - Sync/Map user profile attributes from IDP to Umbraco site user profile fields, and assign roles based on user’s groups in your IDP.
- Member and Backoffice Login - To access your Umbraco site, you have the option to log in through either the member login or the backoffice login. It's possible to use both methods for logging into the site. Whether you choose the member login, backoffice login, or a combination of both, ensure that you have the appropriate credentials for authentication.

Member and Backoffice Login - To access your Umbraco site, you have the option to log in through either the member login or the backoffice login. It's possible to use both methods for logging into the site. Whether you choose the member login, backoffice login, or a combination of both, ensure that you have the appropriate credentials for authentication.
- Multi-Version Support - The miniOrange SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO) Plugin is designed to be compatible with various Umbraco versions, ranging from Umbraco version 7 to Umbraco version 12. Users have the flexibility to select the Umbraco version that best suits their preferences when implementing Single Sign-On (SSO) functionality.

Multi-Version Support - The miniOrange SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO) Plugin is designed to be compatible with various Umbraco versions, ranging from Umbraco version 7 to Umbraco version 12. Users have the flexibility to select the Umbraco version that best suits their preferences when implementing Single Sign-On (SSO) functionality.
- Single Logout - Terminate the user's SSO Session on Umbraco site as well as your Identity Provider (IdP) when the user logs out of your Umbraco site (SP).

Single Logout - Terminate the user's SSO Session on Umbraco site as well as your Identity Provider (IdP) when the user logs out of your Umbraco site (SP).
- Federation Support - Enables you to add the option to allow your users to SSO into your Umbraco site using their identities stored in the Federated Identity Providers.

Federation Support - Enables you to add the option to allow your users to SSO into your Umbraco site using their identities stored in the Federated Identity Providers.

title: How to Install & Upgrade to Paid Version
content:

Click here to login into miniOrange/Xecurify dashboard.

Go to the License - Manage License menu from the bottom left corner.

Open the tab Releases & Downloads tab and download the plugin from the link given there.

Log in to your Umbraco site using an admin account.
